item.title: Trump’s Cuts to Science Funding Could Hurt U.S. Economy, Study Shows
item.description: Reducing federal support for research and development could cause long-run economic damage and reduce government revenue.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman
item.media:credit: Joanna Kulesza for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Trump administration in recent months has sought to cancel or freeze billions of dollars in grants to scientists.

item.title: Chinese Factories Slow in Early Sign of Trade War’s Toll
item.description: A slowdown in commerce between the United States and China caused by escalating tariffs was evident in a report Wednesday on manufacturing activity in April.
item.dc:creator: Daisuke Wakabayashi
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: A garment factory in Guangzhou, China, this month.

item.title: As Trump Cuts Foreign Aid, What Does It Mean for the Gates Foundation?
item.description: As the Trump administration dismantles foreign aid, Bill Gates, whose philanthropy is devoted to global health, is trying to talk to anyone with the president’s ear.
item.dc:creator: Theodore Schleifer and Stephanie Nolen
item.media:credit: Alex Welsh for The New York Times

item.title: Trump Signs Executive Order Walking Back Some Auto Tariffs
item.description: Most levies on imported cars and car parts will remain in place, but automakers have secured some relaxation of the trade policy.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Nic Antaya for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ford assembly plant in Wayne, Mich. Automakers have welcomed any relaxation of tariffs, which they said would raise car prices, cause sales to fall and threaten their financial viability.

item.title: How Trump May Unintentionally Cut Carbon Emissions
item.description: Despite his administration’s lack of concern about climate change, a recession would give the atmosphere a break. At least in the short term.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis
item.media:credit: Maggie Shannon for The New York Times

item.title: With Trump In Power, Foreign Crypto Companies Make Inroads in US
item.description: The prime example is Tether, a firm that regulators once targeted. Its chief executive recently hobnobbed in Washington with lawmakers and lobbyists.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany and Kenneth P. Vogel
item.media:credit: Illustration by Zak Bickel/The New York Times; Photographs by Jussi Puikkonen for The New York Times; Eric Lee/The New York Times

item.title: How Spain’s Success in Renewable Energy May Have Left Its Power Grid Vulnerable
item.description: The Iberian Peninsula’s widespread blackout raises questions about the resilience of the electric power infrastructure in the two countries — and to an extent, the rest of Europe.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed and Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: Jon Nazca/Reuters
item.media:description: Candles burned in the reception area of a hotel in Ronda, Spain, in the early morning on Tuesday, after a power outage across the Iberian Peninsula.

item.title: Retailers Fear Toy Shortages at Christmas as Tariffs Freeze Supply Chain
item.description: Toy makers and stores are freezing holiday orders, predicting shortages and higher prices. Some are consulting bankruptcy lawyers, fearing their firms won’t survive.
item.dc:creator: Daisuke Wakabayashi
item.media:credit: Colin Sussingham for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Aldik Home store in Los Angeles, which sells artificial Christmas trees and other decorations, is running promotions on some of its products before the tariffs take effect.

item.title: UPS to Cut 20,000 Jobs and Slash Amazon Deliveries to Trim Costs
item.description: The move comes as President Trump’s tariffs are reducing shipping volumes and is in addition to 12,000 job cuts last year.
item.dc:creator: Peter Eavis
item.media:credit: Maansi Srivastava/The New York Times
item.media:description: UPS has some 490,000 employees, many of whom are members of the Teamsters union.

item.title: Controllers Briefly Lost Contact With Planes at Newark Last Week, Union Official Says
item.description: The disclosure came as disruptions at the airport, brought about by staffing shortages, runway construction and bad weather, entered a second week.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson, Mark Walker, Christine Hauser and Christine Chung
item.media:credit: Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times
item.media:description: Since last week, travelers have faced lengthy delays at Newark Liberty International Airport because of staffing shortages, equipment problems, construction and inclement weather.

item.title: As Backlash to Trump’s Tariffs Grows, Europe Boycotts American Brands
item.description: A shifting perception of the United States amid President Trump’s trade war is prompting Europeans to pivot decisively away from U.S. goods and services.
item.dc:creator: Liz Alderman
item.media:credit: Christopher Furlong/Getty Images
item.media:description: A Nike store in Rome. European consumers are starting to avoid U.S. products and services, according to a European Central Bank survey.

item.title: Cyberattack on UnitedHealth Leaves Medical Providers in Debt
item.description: The company lent roughly $9 billion to practices affected by a vast cyberattack on its payment systems last year. Medical practices are now suing the health care colossus, saying it is pressuring them to repay funds.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Ryan
item.category: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services
item.media:credit: Caroline Yang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. John Odom, left, and Meghan Klein, at their sports medicine practice in Eden Prairie, Minn.

item.title: Scott Bessent Urges Investors to Bet on Trump’s Economic Plan
item.description: The Treasury secretary urged executives and entrepreneurs to look beyond the Trump administration’s trade agenda.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent has been working to ease concerns among global investors that the president’s trade plans will destabilize the global economy.

item.title: A Reporter Takes Pause at the Career Pause
item.description: Fed up with being overworked or unfulfilled, some young people are quitting their jobs to take “mini-retirements,” a trend that caught the eye of a Times journalist.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Christopher Capozziello for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sandra De La Cruz left her job in the construction industry to take a career hiatus.

item.title: What Buffett’s Exit Means
item.description: Tens of thousands were on hand to see the billionaire announce his plans to retire. Their attention is already focusing on what is next for the conglomerate he built.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Edmund Lee
item.media:credit: Nati Harnik/Associated Press
item.media:description: It’s the end of an era as Berkshire Hathaway’s Warren Buffett has announced he’ll retire by year-end.

item.title: Why Warren Buffett’s Departure from Berkshire Hathaway Matters
item.description: At the annual meeting of Berkshire Hathaway, known as “Woodstock for capitalists,” many wept at the departure of a singular figure in the business world.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin
item.media:credit: Jason Lee/Reuters
item.media:description: Warren Buffett won an enormous following because of his success and his values. His planned exit from Berkshire Hathaway raises questions about what will happen to the enterprise he built.

item.title: Donald Jr. and Eric Trump Pursue New Deals That Would Enrich President Trump
item.description: Donald Trump Jr. and Eric Trump spent the past two weeks traveling the world and announcing new ventures involving billions of dollars.
item.dc:creator: Eric Lipton and David Yaffe-Bellany
item.media:credit: Karim Jaafar/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Eric Trump in Doha, the Qatari capital, on Wednesday, looking over a model of a development the Trump Organization plans to build there.

item.title: The Fed Isn’t Likely to Cut Rates Proactively Despite Economic Concerns. Here’s Why.
item.description: The U.S. central bank is set to reinforce its wait-and-see approach at its meeting this week as President Trump’s tariffs begin to bite.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith
item.media:credit: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Federal Reserve is widely expected to keep interest rates steady when officials gather this week.

item.title: Farmers in Iowa Are Caught in Trump’s Trade War
item.description: With high costs and low prices for their crops, soybean and corn farmers were already nervous as they planned for planting season this year. Tariffs aren’t helping.
item.dc:creator: Julie Creswell

item.title: A Grand Comeback for a Grand Seaside Hotel
item.description: San Diego’s Hotel del Coronado, where “Some Like It Hot” was shot and celebrities regularly checked in, has been renovated meticulously, deliberately and very expensively.
item.dc:creator: Danielle Pergament
item.media:credit: John Francis Peters for The New York Times
item.media:description: When it opened in 1888, the Hotel del Coronado, in San Diego, was the largest hotel in the world.

item.title: Can Late-Night TV Survive Streaming? John Mulaney’s Show Is a Test.
item.description: The talk shows are one of the few TV genres that haven’t made the leap to streaming. Their future may instead look a lot like a podcast studio.
item.dc:creator: John Koblin

item.title: Elon Musk, His 16-Foot Wall and the Feud With His Texas Neighbors
item.description: Residents of an upscale enclave outside Austin, Texas, learned the hard way what it’s like when a multibillionaire moves into the mansion next door. Some of them have started a ruckus over it.
item.dc:creator: Kirsten Grind
item.media:credit: Illustration by Zak Bickel/The New York Times; Photographs by Jordan Vonderhaar for The New York Times; Eric Lee/The New York Times

item.title: China’s Garment Factories Face a Tipping Point After New Tariffs
item.description: As a U.S. tax loophole ends, the apparel makers that sell to America are forced to consider alternative markets or cheaper locations in and outside China.
item.dc:creator: Meaghan Tobin
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: The night shift in the garment district in Guangzhou, China.

item.title: Oil Prices Fall as OPEC Increases Supply Despite Fears of an Economic Slowdown
item.description: U.S. oil prices fell to around $57 a barrel after the OPEC Plus cartel said this weekend that it would pump more oil.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:credit: Ronaldo Schemidt/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: An oil refinery in Deer Park, Texas. For many companies, declining oil prices makes drilling new wells in the United States unprofitable.

item.title: Trump Targets Movies Made Outside U.S. With 100% Tariff, Citing Hollywood’s Decline
item.description: Declaring foreign film production a national security threat, the president said he had asked his top trade official to start the process of imposing a tax on Hollywood.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes
item.category: International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees
item.media:credit: Jenna Schoenefeld for The New York Times
item.media:description: In January, President Trump said he had named Mel Gibson, Sylvester Stallone and Jon Voight as “special ambassadors.”

item.title: Highlights of Warren Buffett’s Life
item.description: Mr. Buffett, 94, was crowned the “Oracle of Omaha” because of smart investments he made as the chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway. He also made some mistakes.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:credit: Johannes Eisele/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Warren Buffett said he started studying the stock market when he was 9 years old.

item.title: How Warren Buffett Changed the Way Investors Thought of Investing
item.description: The idea of “value investing” had long existed. But no one did it as successfully or for as long as he did.
item.dc:creator: Michael J. de la Merced, Maureen Farrell and Lauren Hirsch
item.media:credit: Brendan McDermid/Reuters
item.media:description: Warren E. Buffett, at the Berkshire Hathaway shareholders’ meeting on Saturday, turned a failing textile manufacturer into a trillion-dollar conglomerate and microcosm of the U.S. economy.

item.title: Who Is Gregory Abel, Warren Buffett’s Successor?
item.description: Mr. Buffett won renown and made billions as one of the most successful stock pickers of all time. Mr. Abel’s strengths lie more in running businesses.
item.dc:creator: Michael J. de la Merced
item.media:credit: Brendan Mcdermid/Reuters
item.media:description: Greg Abel, at the Berkshire Hathaway shareholders’ gathering this weekend in Omaha, was Warren Buffett’s yearslong heir apparent.

item.title: My Boss Wants to Sleep on My Couch Every Week
item.description: Boundaries, boundaries and more boundaries. Plus: boundaries.
item.dc:creator: Anna Holmes
item.media:credit: Photo illustration by Margeaux Walter for The New York Times

item.title: Would the Housing Crisis Ease if Boomers Rented Out Their Empty Rooms?
item.description: Millions of single-family homes are underused, on spacious lots. Refitting them for “roommate houses” or backyard cottages could make a difference.
item.dc:creator: Conor Dougherty
item.media:credit: Desiree Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Monte Anderson, a developer in the Dallas area, divided his 2,400-square-foot home into four studio apartments and added a house in the backyard.

item.title: ‘People Who Are Salaried Are Crying’: Taxes on Workers Add to Debt Misery
item.description: Increased payroll taxes are one element of a desperate bid in Kenya to keep the government running and pay off the country’s foreign creditors.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:credit: Brian Otieno for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Toi Market in Nairobi.

item.title: Trump’s Tariffs Create Fear and Uncertainty at Vietnam’s Factories
item.description: The threat of 46 percent levies, among the highest for any country, is rattling Vietnam’s factory managers and workers, as well as thousands of exporters.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson and Tung Ngo
item.media:credit: Linh Pham for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers sew garments along a production line at a Thanh Cong Textile Garment in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam.

item.title: Voters Approve Incorporation of SpaceX Hub as Starbase, Texas
item.description: A South Texas community, mostly made up of SpaceX employees, voted 212 to 6 in favor of establishing a new city called Starbase.
item.dc:creator: Hank Sanders
item.media:credit: Gabriel V. Cárdenas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of a South Texas community that is home to SpaceX and many of its employees voted Saturday to establish the city of Starbase.

item.title: Oil Prices Are Falling. Here’s Where That Could Spell Trouble.
item.description: For countries that depend heavily on oil revenue, dropping prices are worrisome.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gas flares lit the night sky in Punta de Mata, an oil producing area in Venezuela.

item.title: Warren Buffett Plans to Step Down as Berkshire Hathaway CEO by End of 2025
item.description: Mr. Buffett said at the annual shareholders’ meeting that he wanted to turn over the reins to Greg Abel at the end of the year. Earlier, he criticized Trump’s trade policies.
item.dc:creator: Michael J. de la Merced
item.media:credit: Rick Wilking/Reuters
item.media:description: Tens of thousands of investors flocked to Omaha on Saturday to hear directly from Warren E. Buffett, the chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway.

item.title: Why OPEC Plus Is Increasing Oil Supplies Despite Falling Prices
item.description: The group agreed to raise output in June, a sign that Saudi Arabia and its allies appear to be weary of cutting output and may be trying to appease President Trump, who has pushed for lower prices.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oil production has increased at the Tengiz field in Kazakhstan, which is run by a Chevron-led joint venture that includes Exxon Mobil.

item.title: They Help Companies Set Prices. Tariffs Are Making It Trickier.
item.description: Pricing strategists are navigating the possibility that input costs, the economy and consumer behavior may all shift drastically.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Kessler
item.media:credit: Alfredo Estrella/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Many companies are planning to incorporate the costs associated with President Trump’s tariff policies in their pricing. But they fear those costs could change.

item.title: Why Designated Beneficiaries Are Key to Your Estate Planning
item.description: Although a will is crucial to making sure your assets go where you want them when you die, you are likely to need something else, too: designated beneficiaries.
item.dc:creator: Tammy LaGorce
item.category: Center for Retirement Research at Boston College
item.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times
item.media:description: Zygmund Furmaniuk said the paperwork needed to transfer some of his deceased aunt’s assets was “the size of a small phone book.”

item.title: Trump’s Tariff on Cheap Chinese Imports Will Cost Big Tech Billions
item.description: For Meta, Alphabet and other platforms, the elimination of the tariff exemption for inexpensive goods is already cutting into advertising revenue.
item.dc:creator: Daisuke Wakabayashi and Mike Isaac
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Porters move packages through a garment wholesale and distribution district in Guangzhou, China on Thursday.

item.title: Car Prices Expected to Rise as Tariffs on Parts Kick In
item.description: Tariffs on imported parts will have a broad impact because all vehicles use components made abroad.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Stacy Kranitz for The New York Times
item.media:description: A General Motors plant in Bowling Green, Ky. Even vehicles made in the United States often include components that are made in other countries.

item.title: Newark Airport Is Experiencing Major Flight Delays. What’s Causing Them?
item.description: Staffing shortages at an air traffic control center have added to the effects of a runway closure, leading to travel headaches that show no signs of easing.
item.dc:creator: Christine Chung
item.media:credit: Dakota Santiago for The New York Times
item.media:description: United Airlines, which operates an average of 328 round-trip flights a day at Newark Liberty International Airport, said on Friday that it was cutting 35 of those flights because of air traffic control problems.

item.title: Former Abercrombie C.E.O. Ruled Unfit to Stand Trial for Sex Trafficking
item.description: Michael S. Jeffries had been accused of luring male models to secret sex parties. He has dementia, and a judge ruled him to be “mentally incompetent.”
item.dc:creator: Santul Nerkar
item.media:credit: Heather Khalifa/Associated Press
item.media:description: Michael S. Jeffries, who prosecutors said coerced models into sex, had presided over several crises at Abercrombie and Fitch. He left the clothing retailer in 2014.

item.title: Stock Market on Track to Erases Losses From Trump’s ‘Liberation Day’ Tariff Rollout
item.description: Wall Street has recovered from April’s sharp sell-off, buoyed by hope for trade talks. But the economic fallout from President Trump’s policies still has investors on edge.
item.dc:creator: Danielle Kaye

item.title: Trump’s Order to Cut Funding for NPR and PBS Draws Fiery Pushback
item.description: NPR called the order, which could upend public media, “an affront to the First Amendment.”
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mullin
item.media:credit: Eric Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: NPR headquarters in Washington.

item.title: Google Plans to Roll Out Gemini A.I. Chatbot to Children Under 13
item.description: The tech giant said it would make its Gemini chatbot available to children next week, and warned families in an email about the changes.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Singer
item.media:credit: Jim Wilson/The New York Times
item.media:description: The Google chatbot will be available to children under 13 whose parents use Family Link.

item.title: Here’s what to know:
item.dc:creator: Talmon Joseph Smith

item.title: Republicans Wrestle With Trump’s Demands for Tax Cuts
item.description: House Republicans are planning to include several of President Trump’s campaign promises in the first draft of the bill, which they hope to release soon.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Duehren
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: Congressional Republicans are straining to incorporate several of President Trump’s novel tax plans into legislation.

item.title: U.S. and China Dig In on Trade War, With No Plans for Formal Talks
item.description: The standoff over terms of negotiations, and whether they are happening, signals that a protracted economic fight lies ahead.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: The apparent silence between the United States and China is a serious matter for the global economy.

item.title: Trump Proposes $163 Billion in Cuts Across Government in New Budget
item.description: Many of the suggested cuts, which would require congressional approval, target federal programs that benefit the poor.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm

item.title: Solid Jobs Report Reinforces Fed’s Patient Approach to Interest Rate Cuts
item.description: The central bank is bracing for President Trump’s tariffs to dent growth while stoking inflation, keeping interest rate cuts at bay for now.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair.

item.title: Trump Says He’s ‘Taking Away’ Harvard’s Tax Exempt Status
item.description: President Trump on Friday said he would be “taking away” the university’s status, renewing a threat he made last month. It was not immediately clear if the I.R.S. was moving forward with a change.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Duehren, Maggie Haberman and Alan Blinder
item.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times
item.media:description: The campus at Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass.

item.title: Tips for Navigating the ‘Chaotic System’ of Student Loan Repayments
item.description: Experts say recent graduates with loans should choose the repayment option that makes the most sense for them now and expect to make adjustments later.
item.dc:creator: Ann Carrns

item.title: Don’t Count the Dollar Out Just Yet
item.description: As President Trump’s tariffs rock the world, German bonds and the euro are benefiting. But U.S. strength endures, our columnist says.
item.dc:creator: Jeff Sommer

item.title: Why Apple Warned About a $900 Million Tariff Hit
item.description: The iPhone maker warned that it may take a $900 million hit from President Trump’s levies, showing that even powerful companies aren’t immune from the trade war.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Edmund Lee
item.media:credit: Kevin Frayer/Getty Images
item.media:description: The real hit for Apple from tariffs could start in this quarter, to the tune of perhaps $900 million, executives warn Wall Street.

item.title: TikTok Fined $600 Million for Sending European User Data to China
item.description: Irish investigators said TikTok did not protect the data of users in the European Union, improperly transferring some of it to China. TikTok said it would appeal.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano
item.media:credit: Roslan Rahman/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The fine adds to the challenges faced by TikTok’s owner, ByteDance, amid increased scrutiny in the United States.

item.title: Hospitality hiring could slow as foreign tourists skip the U.S., for now.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis
item.media:credit: Janice Chung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Locals and tourists in the Financial District of Manhattan earlier this month.

item.title: Exxon and Chevron Report Lower Profits While Girding for Tariffs
item.description: President Trump’s trade policies have helped to push down oil prices while raising the costs of materials for oil and gas companies.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Many larger oil and gas companies have said they would stick to their production plans for the year.

item.title: President Trump remains bullish, even as the economy flashes warning signs.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump has heralded his pursuit of tax cuts and sky-high tariffs as the ingredients for an imminent economic boom.

item.title: After weeks of volatile trading, Friday’s report could set the tone on Wall Street.
item.dc:creator: Joe Rennison and Danielle Kaye
item.media:credit: Richard Drew/Associated Press
item.media:description: Traders at the New York Stock Exchange on Thursday.
